texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The latest release of the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG)  was published last week . This release is Version 1, Release 3, and it contains four main changes:
texts.text: The latest release of the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG)  was published last week . This release is Version 1, Release 3, and it contains four main changes:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: V-77819 - Multifactor authentication is required for graphical logins
texts.text: V-77819 - Multifactor authentication is required for graphical logins

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: V-77821 - Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module must be disabled
texts.text: V-77821 - Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module must be disabled

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: V-77823 - Single user mode must require user authentication
texts.text: V-77823 - Single user mode must require user authentication

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: V-77825 - Address space layout randomization (ASLR) must be enabled
texts.text: V-77825 - Address space layout randomization (ASLR) must be enabled

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Deep dive
texts.text: Deep dive

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's break down this list to understand what each one means.
texts.text: Let's break down this list to understand what each one means.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: V-77819 - Multifactor authentication is required for graphical logins
texts.text: V-77819 - Multifactor authentication is required for graphical logins

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This requirement improves security for graphical logins and extends the existing requirements for multifactor authentication for logins (see V-71965, V-72417, and V-72427). The STIG recommends smartcards (since the US Government often uses  CAC cards  for multifactor authentication), and this is a good idea for high security systems.
texts.text: This requirement improves security for graphical logins and extends the existing requirements for multifactor authentication for logins (see V-71965, V-72417, and V-72427). The STIG recommends smartcards (since the US Government often uses  CAC cards  for multifactor authentication), and this is a good idea for high security systems.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I use  Yubikey 4's  as smartcards in most situations and they work anywhere you have available USB slots.
texts.text: I use  Yubikey 4's  as smartcards in most situations and they work anywhere you have available USB slots.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: V-77821 - Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module must be disabled
texts.text: V-77821 - Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module must be disabled

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: DCCP  is often used as a congestion control mechanism for UDP traffic, but it isn't used that often in modern networks. There have been  vulnerabilities  in the past that are mitigated by disabling DCCP, so it's a good idea to disable it unless you have a strong reason for keeping it enabled.
texts.text: DCCP  is often used as a congestion control mechanism for UDP traffic, but it isn't used that often in modern networks. There have been  vulnerabilities  in the past that are mitigated by disabling DCCP, so it's a good idea to disable it unless you have a strong reason for keeping it enabled.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The ansible-hardening role has been updated to  disable the DCCP kernel module by default .
texts.text: The ansible-hardening role has been updated to  disable the DCCP kernel module by default .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: V-77823 - Single user mode must require user authentication
texts.text: V-77823 - Single user mode must require user authentication

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Single user mode is often used in emergency situations where the server cannot boot properly or an issue must be repaired without a fully booted server. This mode can only be used at the server's physical console, serial port, or via out-of-band management (DRAC, iLO, and IPMI). Allowing single-user mode access without authentication is a serious security risk.
texts.text: Single user mode is often used in emergency situations where the server cannot boot properly or an issue must be repaired without a fully booted server. This mode can only be used at the server's physical console, serial port, or via out-of-band management (DRAC, iLO, and IPMI). Allowing single-user mode access without authentication is a serious security risk.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fortunately, every distribution supported by the ansible-hardening role already has authentication requirements for single user mode in place. The ansible-hardening role does not make any adjustments to the single user mode unit file since any untested adjustment could cause a system to have problems booting.
texts.text: Fortunately, every distribution supported by the ansible-hardening role already has authentication requirements for single user mode in place. The ansible-hardening role does not make any adjustments to the single user mode unit file since any untested adjustment could cause a system to have problems booting.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: V-77825 - Address space layout randomization (ASLR) must be enabled
texts.text: V-77825 - Address space layout randomization (ASLR) must be enabled

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ASLR  is a handy technology that makes it more difficult for attackers to guess where a particular program is storing data in memory. It's not perfect, but it certainly raises the difficulty for an attacker. There are multiple settings for this variable and the  kernel documentation for sysctl  has some brief explanations for each setting (search for
texts.text: ASLR  is a handy technology that makes it more difficult for attackers to guess where a particular program is storing data in memory. It's not perfect, but it certainly raises the difficulty for an attacker. There are multiple settings for this variable and the  kernel documentation for sysctl  has some brief explanations for each setting (search for

texts.label: code
texts.orig: randomize_va_space
texts.text: randomize_va_space

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: on the page).
texts.text: on the page).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every distribution supported by the ansible-hardening role is already setting
texts.text: Every distribution supported by the ansible-hardening role is already setting

texts.label: code
texts.orig: kernel.randomize_va_space=2
texts.text: kernel.randomize_va_space=2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: by default, which applies randomization for the basic parts of process memory (such as shared libraries and the stack) as well as the heap. The ansible-hardening role will ensure that the default setting is maintained.
texts.text: by default, which applies randomization for the basic parts of process memory (such as shared libraries and the stack) as well as the heap. The ansible-hardening role will ensure that the default setting is maintained.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: ansible-hardening is already up to date
texts.text: ansible-hardening is already up to date

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're already using the ansible-hardening role's master branch, these changes are  already in place ! Try out the new updates and  open a bug report  if you find any problems.
texts.text: If you're already using the ansible-hardening role's master branch, these changes are  already in place ! Try out the new updates and  open a bug report  if you find any problems.
